bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to [Wade Hampton Frost], September 30, 1928

div1.p: Carter writes Frost about bibliographical references to the History of Yellow Fever manuscript.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to [Wade Hampton Frost], September 30, 1928

opener.dateline:
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
September 30, 1928.

div1.p:
Your very welcome letter of September 28th. containing news of
your progress on editing the yellow fever manuscript reached me yester-
day.

(1) Re the card for Peryassu: I'm sorry the reference was so in-
volved, so am sending a white card, leaving out irrelevent matters. Yes,
I verified the statement, or rather Dr. Harrison G. Dyar and I did so
together in his copy of “Os culicideos do Brazil” (1908) P. 397.

(Re): Re Goeldi, (i. p.8 Father's MSS) reporting occurrence of ae-
gypti larvae in street gutters: (a) The letter from Dr. M. E. Connor,
which I am sending you states (last paragraph Page i) that he is cer-
tain that Goeldi mentions aegypti breeding in street gutters. I have looked for
it carefully in “Os mosquitos no Pará” without finding it, however, and
although I may have overlooked it, I am generally pretty careful. (b) Also
as you say, the fact that Howard, Dyar and Knab (p.284) quote Durham
and to the above effect would make him a satisfactory substitute, although
“rain gutters” and “street gutters” are not always the same thing: all
street gutters, in working order, can act as rain gutters, but many rain
gutters are on on the roofs of houses and with frequent stoppage of flow by
leaves etc, wouldn't they be more apt to encourage aegypti breeding than
street gutters? Of course, I don't know Pará, and there may be no rain
gutters save those in the streets.

(3) What's wrong with our friend Warren, H? I am under the im-
pression that we read his original article and made out a verified ref.
card for him.

(4) Re Nott:(Josiah Clark): I am mailing you the bound vols.
of the New Orleans Med. & Surg. Journal containing the accounts of
of
-2-
(a) the yellow fever epidemics of 1842 and '43 and (b) that of 1853.
The first two epidemics Nott did not regard as contagious. That of
1853, as you say, impressed him with the evidence of contagiousness.
When you finish with these bound volumes, will you please send them
back to me by insured mail, at my home address:
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N.W.
Washington, D. C.

Also, I would be grateful if you would send them back at your earliest
convenience, lest there be a call for them from the Library.

(c): I am also sending you Father's notes on Nott, with the pagination
I think you'll specially want indicated with a red pencil marks: (d) I
am also sending Section i: Epidemiology from which your clear copy was
made, as on pages 22 and 23 you will find the refs. to Nott's reports of
the epidemics of 1842 & '43 and (on page 23 to that of 1853). also attached to this page, verbatim quotations from Nott re these epidemics (1842 &'43 also 1853) You are
right in thinking that reference to the last as to “the epidemic of 18543”
was a typographical error, but it was in theyour clear copy, not in the MSS
I am sending you. The ref. on page 36 to the 1843 epidemic is correct, I think,
only it should be 1842 and 1843.

I am awfully sorry for you to have so much more of the drudgery
of the final editing than would have been necessary had there only been a
carbon of the clear copy of the book. In that case Miss Brown and I
could have filled in everything in it save the few doubtful points and saved
you a lot of work. As it is, I expect we shall have to send you the MSS
with which we have been working, as the cards are only supplemental to
it in the case of long verbatim quotations. I am sorry our MSS is so mark-
ed up, but the winter I was staying in Baltimore, I understood that you
intended to correct it before the clear copy was made, hence I inserted
all sorts of marginal Mem. about which to ask you.

(5): I am also sending over to you an additional enclosure from Mr.
Van Wesep re the 2nd rRef. to Carr's work at Parahyba and (5') Connor's
Connor's
-3-
verified refs., as well as his letter from which they were taken.

I shall be very glad to go over to Baltimore whenever you want
me and hope that the next time I do so you w will let me bring Miss
Brown also, as while it is my intention and expectation to “last”
until I am no longer needed in connection with the book, I think it
would be well for her to have met you “por si acaso,” as the Spaniards
say--i. e. “in case”-- Also, I think she could the more easily explain
any puzzling matters as to the library cards etc. if she could talk
with you. Lastly, I think it would be very interesting for her to
meet you. Miss Brown, like myself, is an early riser, so that we could
easily get off on the 9 o'clok train any morning and be at your office by
ten. Also, we could stay in turn over night if you needed us for longer
than a day.

I am extremely glad that you suggested to Dr. Russell having
the MSS retyped in duplicate or triplicate in Baltimore. The copies
(mainly made for Dr. Beeuwkes) in the New York, (I. H. B.) offices in 1927
were poor--material transposed as well as many typographical errors.
It was very thoughtful of you to tell me about Dr. Russell being
pleased with the progress of the work.
div1.closer:
With love to the Susans and all manner of grateful affection to
yourself,
Most truly your friend, Laura A. Carter Dr. Wade H. Frost,
School of Hygiene and Public Health,
615 North Wolfe Street,
Baltimore, Md.
Some Eenclosures. the rest to follow by registered mail tomorrow
(Monday)
P. S. This is written in a hurry after working too long and and too
hard[unclear] I hope, however, that that I have not left out any essentials: At
any rate, if any cards aren't clear just ship them back and we'll have
very little trouble in making them so.
L
